awd_titl_txt: Transport, evolution, and induced mixing of bubble swarms across pycnoclines
awd_abstract_narration:
The density of water in lakes and oceans is far from uniform; it varies over length scales from meters to a kilometer. This variation in density (or density stratification) can be due to two reasons: i) thermal, wherein the density varies due to variations in local temperature or, ii) saline, wherein the density varies due to variations in the salt concentration. The subsurface layers across which this change in density is observed are called pycnoclines. Researchers often neglect the effects of density stratification on the motion of rising bubbles and droplets and the induced mixing of the background fluid. However, the PIs showed that such density gradients can significantly affect the ascent of small drops by enhancing the drag experienced by them. Quantifying the impact of density stratification on bubbles and drops is an essential, yet under-explored area of fluid dynamics, and the need to better understand this area is prevalent in different multiphase phenomena pertaining to lakes and oceans, for example, destratification of water reservoirs by air-bubble plume systems, release of methane in marine sediments, dispersion of an oil plume during an oil spill, and the use of artificially generated bubble plumes to lower surface temperatures in order to arrest excessive evaporation from lakes. The new physical insights to be gained in this study, along with the numerical techniques that have been and will be developed, will be significantly beneficial for a broad range of other researchers who are devoted at the interface between fluid dynamics, hydrology, and oceanography.  

This research will use state-of-the-art, experimentally validated computational tools to quantify the effects of density stratification on (1) the mixing of the background fluid by laminar bubbly upflows in density stratification, (2) the migration velocity and microstructure formation of bubble/droplet swarms, and (3) the mixing and the motions of bubbles/drops in the presence of background turbulence. The research will pave the way to systematically investigate the motion of multiphase flows at pycnoclines and the resultant mixing. The extent of mixing will be quantified by computing the mixing efficiency (a measure of the rate of increase in background potential energy due to mixing against the rate of dissipation of kinetic energy in the process), the diapycnal eddy diffusivity (a measure of mixing due to vertical transport of the fluid) and the temperature micro-structure. The properties of the bubble/droplet swarms will be quantified by calculating the drift velocity and the fluctuation velocities of the dispersed and continuous phases, and pair probability distribution functions for the dispersed phase.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The density of water in lakes and oceans varies over length scales from meters to a few kilometers. This variation can be due to temperature or salinity gradient. Despite these facts, researchers often neglect the effects of density stratification on the motion of rising bubbles and droplets and the induced mixing of the background fluid. Quantifying the impact of density stratification on monodisperse and polydisperse bubbles and drops is an essential, yet an underexplored area of fluid dynamics. The need to better understand this phenomenon is prevalent in different multiphase systems pertaining to lakes and oceans, for instance, destratification of water reservoirs by air-bubble plume systems, the release of methane in marine sediments, dispersion of oil plume during an oil spill, and the use of artificially generated bubble plumes to lower surface temperatures to arrest excessive evaporation from lakes.

PIs developed new state-of-the-art numerical tools to address these problems. Specifically, we quantified various parameters involved in the rising motion of bubbles/droplets in stratified fluids, which are not accessible by other techniques. The numerical tools was used to predict and measure quantitatively the impact of density stratification on suspensions bubbles.

To adequately comprehend bubbly flows in stratified fluids, PIs investigated the dynamics of bubbles/droplet swarms in stratified fluid, a challenge that was largely unanswered before these contributions. The findings from the studies performed under the auspices of this grant have advanced our understanding of bubble motion, microstructure formation and their induced mixing. Investigations on the bubble dynamics and mixing induced in stratified fluids by the bubble motion in a Hele-Shaw cell showed that bubbles follow a zig-zag motion and also form clusters briefly before breaking. The mixing efficiency increases as the stratification increases. Another study which considered a swarm of bubbles in an unbounded stratified fluid concluded that highly deformable, high Reynolds number bubbles undergo path instabilities and give rise to higher levels of mixing. They also observed that as the stratification strength increases, the turbulent kinetic energy levels decrease, indicating increasing stability and resistance to destratification.

Experiments on the mixing induced by spherical and cylindrical objects settling in a stratified fluid showed that as the light fluid is dragged to larger depths by these settling objects, the amount of energy generated for mixing and the change in total potential energy of the system is higher. Spheres are thus more efficient in disturbing volumes of fluid but cylinders are more efficient in causing irreversible changes to the state of the system. On the theoretical front, PIs showed that for a drop of constant density and uniform interfacial tension rising in a linearly density stratified fluid, stratification or inertia increase the drag, and theoretically derived this enhanced drag acting on a drop.

The finding from the efforts under this grant have been published in high impact journals like the Journal of Fluid Mechanics, Journal of Computational Physics, Soft Matter, Physical Review Fluid, Physical Review E, Journal of Rheology, Frontiers in microbiology, Microfluidics and nanofluidics, International Journal of Multiphase flows.

This project has had a strong educational and outreach component. PIs organized For Your Imagination (FYI) workshop for Women in Engineering Program in multiple summers. 100 female middle school students participated in this workshop. Simple hands-on experiments were designed and conducted for students to engage and attract them to STEM fields. 6 Ph.D. students and 1 masters students have been trained as a part of this grant. Aspects of this research has been included in the graduate course: “Low Reynolds Hydrodynamics”, offered fall 2019 & 2021. PIs have organized several minisymposia on complex fluids, hydrodynamics of swimming organisms and motion in stratified fluid within meeting of SoR, IUTAM and AIChE, as well as dedicated conferences, 30th International Conference on Parallel Computational Fluid Dynamics and Cell Motility in Dynamic Environments. PIs have mentored junior faculty on topics such as promotion and tenure, grant writing, recruiting and mentoring graduate students, publishing, teaching and achieving work-life balance. They advised senior design teams to develop a portable water desalination device to obtain purified water for drinking and a portable irrigation tool.

 


Last Modified: 09/07/2021
Modified by: Arezoo Ardekani

Images (1 of )
  • Temperature disturbances and bubble shapes for a swarm of bubbles with volume fraction = 3.66 % rising at Froude number=14.1, Reynolds number Re=100 and different Bond numbers a) 1.55, b) 4.95. The developed numerical tool is used to quantify mixing and destratification.
    M. Ganesh, S. Dabiri
    Copyrighted
    Arezoo Ardekani
    Mixing induced by bubbles in a stratified fluid
  • Bubble trajectories in a swarm of bubbles with volume fractions a) 3.35 %, b) 8.37 %, c) 13.4 % at a fixed stratification strength. The oscillating trajectories are a direct consequence of periodic vortex shedding behind bubbles.
    Reprinted with permission from Maathangi Ganesh, Sangkyu Kim, and Sadegh Dabiri , �Induced mixing in stratified fluids by rising bubbles in a thin gap� Phys. Rev. Fluids 5, 043601, 2020. DOI:https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevFluids.5.043601
    Copyrighted
    Arezoo Ardekani
    Trajectory of bubbles in a stratified fluid
  • a) Flow field and b) temperature contours for a swarm of bubbles with volume fraction 8.37 % rising in a stratified fluid with Froude number = 6.37. Stratification fundamentally changes the trajectories, interaction, and the mixing induced by the rising swarm of bubbles.
    M. Ganesh, S. Kim, S. Dabiri Physical Review Fluids, 2020
    Copyrighted
    Arezoo Ardekani
    Flow field generated by a swarm of bubbles in a stratified fluid
  • A novel numerical scheme is developed by the PIs to accurately resolve multiphase multicomponent flows, dissolving interfaces and mixing.
    Reprinted figure with permission from Z. Huang, G. Lin, A.M. Ardekani �A consistent and conservative model and its scheme for N-phase-M-component incompressible�, Journal of Computational Physics, 434, 110229, 2021. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2021.110229
    Copyrighted
    Arezoo Ardekani
    Miscible drops falling in a fluid reservoir
  • A novel numerical scheme is developed by the PIs to accurately resolve multiphase multicomponent flows, interfaces, moving contact lines and mixing.
    Reprinted figure with permission from Z. Huang, G. Lin, A.M. Ardekani �A consistent and conservative model and its scheme for N-phase-M-component incompressible�, Journal of Computational Physics, 434, 110229, 2021. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2021.110229
    Arezoo Ardekani
    Immiscible drops falling in a fluid reservoir with moving contact lines
